Bulk Storage Sites.source: 2016 EPCRA TRI sites from US EPA. DEC active MOSF, CBS and superfund class 2 sites (7/18/2018) from NYS DEC and NYS DEC
Bulk Storage Sites.text: Many sources of toxic waste such as TRI, MOSF, PBS and CBS sites as well as superfund class 2 sites are located in or near SMIAs. This represents a public health threat in the even of a storm surge.

Heat Vulnerability Index.source: Heat Vulnerability Index 2010, by community district. Downloaded at NYC health. Community district shapefiles from NYC planning
Heat Vulnerability Index.text: Heat vulnerability Index (HVI) measures how vulnerable a neighborhood is to heat compared to other neighborhoods on a scale of 1 (low risk) - 5 (high risk). HVI is relative, such that lower numbers do not indicate zero risk, but lower risk compared other neighborhoods.

Hurricane Evacuation Zones.source: Hurricane Evacuation zones from NYC Emergency Management, downloaded from NYC Open Data
Hurricane Evacuation Zones.text: SMIAs are in hurricane evacuation zones and highly vulnerable to hurricanes.

Hurricane Storm Surge Zones.text: The SMIAs and their surroundings are highly vulnerable to hurricane storm surge. Facilities handling hazardous substances or toxic chemicals in these areas could represent a threat in the event of a hurricane storm storm surge. Median Household Income.text: People living near SMIAs tend to have lower median household income.

None.source: SMIA boundaries obtained from NYC WRP. Half mile to SMIA obtained from NYC EJA.
None.text: There are seven SMIAs (outlined in solid black) as well as a half mile buffer to SMIAs (outlined in a dashed line) to determine communities located in close proximity. Half a mile is the distance often used to study environmental impact under NY's environmental regulatory framework.

Percent People of Color.source: US Census 2010, divided by census tract, downloaded from CENSUS.IRE.ORG
Percent People of Color.text: As you can see, the majority of areas around SMIAs represent populations of color. In fact, of the total 5.5 million people of color in NYC, 2.8 million in census tracts that are vulnerable to storm surge and approximately 430,000 live in census tracts that are both vulnerable to storm surage and fall with a half-mile of SMIAs.

Percent Uninsured.source: Percent uninsured data from Community Health Survey 2016 (?), sorted by community district. Downladed at NYC health, community district shapefiles from NYC planning
Percent Uninsured.text: People living in SMIAs also are less likely to have health insurance, which would be dangerous in the event of toxic exposure. Hatched areas represent estimates that should be interpreted with caution.

Percent of Families Below Poverty Line.source: US Census 2010, divided by census tract, downloaded from US Census Bureau
Percent of Families Below Poverty Line.text: People below poverty level are disproportionally present near SMIAs. In fact of the total X million low-income population in NYC. 1.6 million live in census tracts that are vulnerable to hurricane storm surge, and 283,000 live in census tracts that are both vulnerable to storm surge and fall within a half-mile of SMIAs.

Zoning.source: NYC Zoning designations, last updated 2015(?), downloaded from data.Beta.NYC
Zoning.text: Industrial and manufacturing zones (purple) are concentrated in SMIAs. These areas are surrounded by residential zones (yellow). Note that this map does not take into account non-conforming uses where former manufacturing buildings are being used for residential use, as is the case in Greenpoint or Williamsburg.

Brooklyn Navy Yard.description: The Brooklyn Navy Yard is a 227-acre publicly owned industrial park characterized by a diversity of small businesses. The Navy Yard has more than 2,000 permanent jobs on site, and provides an estimated 3,000 temporary jobs to crews of film and television shoots at Steiner Studios. The robust increase in business activity between 200 and 2008 is attributed to a dramatic redevelopment effort, harnessing more than $500 million in public and private investment.

Introduction.description: As the threats of climate change increase, destructive storms like Superstorm Sandy, Hurricane Katrina, and Hurricane Harvey will expose the vulnerabilities of costal communities overburdened by industrial and chemical facilities. Of interest are NYC’s Significant Maritime and Industrial Areas (SMIAs), clusters of industry and polluting infrastructure along the waterfront. SMIAs are located in classic environmental justice communities- predominantly low-income communities of color - in the south Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, which are also hurricane storm surge zones. The WJP is a research and advocacy campaign focusing on community resiliency that seeks to reduce potential toxic exposures and public health risks associated with climate change and storm surge in the City’s industrial waterfront.

Kill Van Kull.description: The Kill Van Kull SMIA stretches from Howland Hook to Snug Harbor. It contains a concentration of maritime uses including a marine terminal and dry docks for ship repair. The SMIA is approximately 665 acres and zoned to permit a broad range of commercial and industrial uses. In 2008, there were more than 70 firms employing more than 3,300 people in the SMIA. The overwhelming number of jobs - more than 70 percent - were in transportation and warehousing.

Newtown Creek.description: Newtown Creek, at over 780 acres the city’s largest SMIA, abuts portions of the Greenpoint, Williamsburg, Long Island City, and Maspeth industrial areas. The waterfront area is characterized by heavy industry and municipal facilities, many of which are water-dependent.

Red Hook.description: The Red Hook SMIA is approximately 120 acres and is more than 90 percent publicly owned. The SMIA is home to the Red Hook Container Terminal and Brooklyn Piers Port Authority Marine Terminal.

South Bronx.description: The South Bronx SMIA is more than 850 acres in size, stretching from Port Morris on the Harlem River to Hunts Point on the East River. Wholesale trade is the dominant industry. The SMIA is home to the city\'s produce distribution center at Hunts Point, the Fulton Fish market, and other food distributors.

Staten Island West Shore.description: No information about this SMIA yet.

Sunset Park.description: Nearly 600 acres, the Sunset Park SMIA extends from Erie Basin to Owl\'s Head, an area characterized by water-dependent facilities, concentrations  of  industrial  activity,  well-buffered  manufacturing  districts,  and  vacant  sites  and  brownfields  of  significant  size.  A  small portion of the SMIA abuts the Gowanus Canal, a waterway that was designated a Superfund Site in 2010.
